properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today into tonight. Snow squalls are expected to intermittently affect the area until Saturday. Snowfall amounts near 5 cm are possible today with an additional 5 cm possible tonight. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T02:37:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T10:38:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0902337157.2021
Area: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this afternoon. Areas south and southeast of Lake Simcoe may be affected by snow squalls this afternoon into the evening. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible by Saturday morning. Locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities in blowing snow will make travel difficult at times. Travellers should consider adjusting their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: 25 to 50 cm through Saturday, with additional amounts expected into Sunday. Higher amounts possible inland. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h. Locations: southeastern Labrador from Lodge Bay to Rigolet. Time span: Friday through the weekend. Remarks: Snow will continue through today and become heavy at times tonight. The fresh snowfall will combine with strong northeasterly winds to reduce visibilities in blowing snow beginning near midnight tonight. There is currently some uncertainty as to when the storm will end. Poor travel conditions may persist through the weekend. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-23T01:09:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T09:10:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3337110504.2021
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls continue. Local heavy snow squalls are expected to continue tonight and affect the area intermittently until Saturday. Up to 15 cm of new snowfall is possible tonight. An additional local 15 cm is possible Friday with an additional 15 cm possible Friday night. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will rapidly accumulate. Snow squalls will intermittently affect the area until Saturday night. Snowfall amounts of 20 cm are possible today. Even heavier snowfall amounts in the 15 to 25 cm range are possible tonight, particularly over Southern Bruce County. On Saturday, an additional 15 cm of snowfall is possible. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for significant snowfall beginning this morning. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, likely higher in some areas of heaviest snow bands. Locations: Annapolis, Kings, Queens, and Lunenburg and Halifax counties. Time span: Beginning this morning and ending in the evening. Remarks: Periods of snow, at times heavy, are expected across parts of Nova Scotia today as a small but potentially vigorous weather system develops and passes just off the Atlantic coast. Given the nature of this system, details as to where the highest snowfall amounts will occur could still be subject to change, and as such this statement may need to be extended to additional regions or upgraded to a snowfall warning for some areas. Regardless, the timing of the snow will likely have impacts on the evening commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T01:44:04-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Valemount due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-23T02:26:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-01-22T10:27:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0277249512.2021
Area: Yellowhead

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather continuing this morning. Additional snowfall: up to 5 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly near 80 km/h along the coast. Locations: the northeast coast from Clarenville to Green Bay - White Bay, excluding the Bonavista Peninsula and Bonavista North. Time span: continuing until early afternoon. Remarks: Snow will continue along the northeast coast this morning along with moderate to strong northwesterly winds, occasionally reducing visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. The wind will be most intense along Notre Dame Bay and over Fogo Island. Conditions will improve this morning over most regions, except for more northern coastal areas, which will remain in snow and blowing snow until this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-22T22:59:33-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue tonight. Locally heavy snow squalls continue to move southward along the Bruce Peninsula and will move out of the area near midnight tonight. Snow squalls may redevelop early Friday morning and persist for a few hours. Up to 20 cm of new snowfall can be expected locally by Friday morning. Additional flurries are possible Friday into Friday night, but snow squalls are not expected at this time. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm, with higher amounts possible over northernmost sections. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 50 km/h, with higher local gusts over the Canada Bay area. Locations: Port Saunders and the Straits, Northern Peninsula East. Time span: continuing until Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will continue today over the Great Northern Peninsula, lasting until Saturday morning. Strong winds will develop on this morning, causing reduced visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. The highest snowfall rates are expected to occur this afternoon and into the overnight hours. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
